H2 Blockers.SPECIFIC USES:
mild-moderate, infrequent episodic heartburn,
GERD,
peptic ulcer disease
H2 Blockers.MOA: block H2 receptor (decrease acid secretion from parietal cells of stomach)
H2 Blockers.DDI: careful w/ drugs that depend on acid for proper absorption (ketoconazole, itraconazole, calcium carbonate, iron salts, protease inhibitors)
H2 Blockers.ADRS:
headache,
dizziness,
fatigue,
consfusion,
dose related gynecomastia (cimetidine only),
tolerance can develop w/ daily use
H2 Blockers.FACTS:
well absorbed,
well tolerated,
self treatment should be limited to no more than twice a day for 2 weeks,
best if only taken PRN,
onset of action: 30-45 min,
duration of relief: 4-10hrs
H2 Blockers.DOSING: available OTC and Rx (OTC usually half Rx doses)

SSRI's.SPECIFIC USES:
Major Depressive Disorder,
anxiety disorders (GAD, OCD, panic disorder, PTSD)
SSRI's.ACTIONS:
presynaptic inhibition of serotonin reuptake pump,
↑5-HT in synapse results in neuronal adaptation (not immediate effect)
SSRI's.ADRS:
diarrhea (5-HT4),
N/V (5-HT3),
headache (5-HT1),
somnolence/messed up sleep cycle (5-HT2),
*sexual dysfunction/loss of libido (5-HT2),
weight gain (rare) 
(5-HTc),
elongated QTc

mood stabilizer.SPECIFIC USES:
bipolar disorder,
adjunt treatment in MDD,
mania,
depressed episodes
mood stabilizer.ACTIONS:
reduce suicidal ideations,
stabilize mood (not well understood MOA),
neuroprotective effects?
mood stabilizer.DDI's:
NSAIDs,
thiazide diuretics,
ACE inhibitors,
calcium channel blockers 
(all increase lithium levels)
mood stabilizer.ADRS:
sedation,
cognitive difficulties,
dry mouth,
hand tremor,
increased appetite,
weight gain,
polydipsia,
polyuria,
nausea,
diarrhea,
acne,
psoriasis,
nephrogenic diabetes insipidus,
renal failure,
hypothyroidism,
mild leukocytosis,
↑free Ca levels,
SA node blockade
mood stabilizer.FACTS:
very narrow therapeutic index (easily toxic),
therapeutic range: 0.5-1.2 mEq/L,
toxicity effects vary based on lithium levels (see chart in slides),
monitor lithium levels, thryroid function, renal function,
teratogenic (Ebstein's anomaly: malformation of tricuspid valve)

anxiolytics.FACTS:
lethal in overdose,
modern use is rare,
less seletively anxiolytic

anxiolytics.SPECIFIC USES:
acute anxiety,
chronic use debated,
insomnia
anxiolytics.ACTIONS: enhance GABA effect by binding benzo receptor on GABAA(allow Cl influx to inhibit neuron firing),
anxiolytics.DDI's: CNS depressants (alcohol, opiates, barbiturates) --> respiratory depression
anxiolytics.ADRS:
sedation (tolerance in 2 weeks),
cognitive impairment,
ataxia/incoordination,
respiratory depression,
anterograde amnesia,
paradoxical agitation (rare),
raises seizure threshold,
overdose (hypotension, respiratory depression, coma)
anxiolytics.FACTS:
cross tolerance w/ alcohol,
rapid dose escalation can induce tolerance,
potential for abuse,
acute withdrawal symptoms worse w/ short half-life benzos,
DO NOT USE IN: liver disease, hx substance abuse, severe respiratory distress, performing hazardous tasks,
avoid in pregnancy/lactation

anxiolytics.FACTS 2:
short half life,
high potency,
fast acting

benzodiazepine antagonist.FACTS: short half life (may require multiple doses to counter benzo overdose since half life is shorter than all benzo's)

Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE) Inhi.SPECIFIC USES/FACTS:
hypertension/post MI,
left ventricular systolic dysfunction/ systolic heart failure,
chronic kidney disease (CKD)
Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE) Inhi.ACTIONS:
↓TPR/BP,
↓ Na/H2O retention,
↓ H2O ingestion,
↓arterial pressure,
↑compliance of large arteries,
↓ proteinuria
Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE) Inhi.ADRS:
dry cough,
hyperkalemia,
acute renal failure/injury,
angioedema,
teratogenic,
hypotension
Angiotensin Converting Enzyme (ACE) Inhi.Facts: Can cause acute renal failure when starting therapy or when changing doses. Has reduced efficacy in African Americans b/c pts have low renin hypertension

Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARB's).SPECIFIC USES/FACTS:
hypertension/post MI/heart failure,
CKD,
intolerance to ACEI,
gout?
Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARB's).ACTIONS:
↓TPR/BP,
↓ Na/H2O retention,
↓ H2O ingestion,
↓arterial pressure,
↑compliance of large arteries,
↓ proteinuria
Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARB's).ADRS:
hyperkalemia,
acute kidney failure/injury,
angioedema,
teratogenic,
hypotension
Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARB's).Facts: If pt is on ARB and also has gout may favor losartan as it has a seconrdary uric acid lowering benefit.  Has reduced efficacy in African Americans b/c pts have low renin hypertension.

NSAIDs.ACTIONS: reduces TXA2 effects on platelets, inhibits platelets
NSAIDs.ADRS:
GI bleed/ulcers,
iron deficiency anemia,
Reye's syndrome (liver failure, encephalopathy) if w/ viral infection in children
NSAIDs.FACTS:
used only in low dose (75-325mg),
high dose has similar effect to NSAIDs but causes too many ADRS,
C/I: hemophelia

NSAIDs.SPECIFIC USES: osteoarthritis, RA, moderate pain, other NSAID intolerance
NSAIDs.ADRS: ↑cardiovascular events, fewer GI ADRS than general COX inhibitors
NSAIDs.FACTS:
sulfa allergy?,
black box warning: ↑ risk for MI/stroke

NSAIDs.SPECIFIC USES:
pain relief,
treat PDA in premature infants
NSAIDs.DRUG-DRUG INTERACTIONS: shouldn't be used w/ aspirin due to increased GI upset
NSAIDs.ACTIONS:
non-selective COX inhibitor (↓TXA2, ↓PGI2, ↓PGE2),
↓platelet aggregation,
vasoconstriction,
temp. control,
↓mucous secretion in stomach,
↓inflammation,
↓pain perception
NSAIDs.ADRS:
headaches,
tinnitus,
dizziness,
hypertension,
edema,
fluid retention,
abdominal pain,
dysplasia,
n/v,
GI ulcers/bleeding,
thrombocytopenia,
neutropenia,
aplastic anemia,
liver failure,
asthma,
renal insufficiency,
hyperkalemia,
proeinuria,
hypersensitivity reactions can occur

Spasmolytics.SPECIFIC USES: spasm of any origin (most effective in cord resection)
Spasmolytics.ACTIONS: stimulates K influx which hyperpolarizes neurons (less action potentials)
Spasmolytics.FACTS:
can accumulate in fat,
caution in elderly pt's,
can be non-selective in spinal cord,
rapid acting (lipophillic)

Spasmolytics.SPECIFIC USES:
muscle spasticity,
mobility in MS,
spinal cord injury
Spasmolytics.ACTIONS:
inhibit Ca entry presynaptically (less glutamate released),
stimulate K efflux postsynaptically (hyperpolarization)
Spasmolytics.DDI's: careful w/ other CNS depressants, will have additive effect
Spasmolytics.ADRS:
sedation,
drowsiness,
lost motor control,
muscle weakness (dose related),
abrupt withdrawal reaction (hyperpyrexia, rebound spasticity, muscular rigidity, rhabdomyolysis, seizures)
Spasmolytics.FACTS:
tolerance to sedation & symptomatic relief,
given PO or IT

Spasmolytics.SPECIFIC USES:
muscle spasticity, 
MS,
spinal cord injury
Spasmolytics.ACTIONS:
inhibit Ca entry presynaptically (less glutamate released),
MIGHT reduce action potentials
Spasmolytics.ADRS:
sedation,
drowsiness,
xerostomia,
hypotension,
bradycardia (more w/ clonidine),
loss of strength,
abrupt withdrawal (rebound HTN, tachycardia, hypertonia/spasticity)
Spasmolytics.FACTS:
equal efficacy to diazepam & baclofen,
sedation/drowsiness more than others,
less muscle weakness than baclofen,
less cardiac impact

General IV Anesthetics.ACTIONS:
GABA-A agonist,
sedative/hypnotic,
↓cerebral blood flow,
↓ICP,
antiemetic
General IV Anesthetics.ADRS:
propofol infusion syndrome (lipemia, rhabdomyolysis, acidosis),
↑HR,
hypotension
General IV Anesthetics.FACTS:
"milk of amnesia",
anesthetic of choice,
no analgesia effect (often given w/ opioid),
long infusion does not affect half life

General IV Anesthetics.ACTIONS:
dissocitive anesthesia,
analgesic effect,
trancelike unconscious state (low-dose),
prevent reuptake of chatecholamines,
alpha-1 & beta-1 agonist,
NMDA non-competative receptor antagonist
General IV Anesthetics.ADRS:
emergence phenomenon (hallucinations/dysphoria),
↑cerebral blood flow,
↑ICP,
↑HR,
↑MAP (mean arterial pressure),
↑CO (cardiac output)
General IV Anesthetics.FACTS:
no effect on respirations,
often used to sedate animals,
can be given IV or IM

General IV Anesthetics.SPECIFIC USES: induction to anesthesia (not for long term use)
General IV Anesthetics.FACTS:
limited use as continuous infusion,
caution in pt w/ seizures,
DOC for cardiovascular/hemodynamically unstable (minimal effect on CO, HR, MAP)

4. pain
5. light touch

toxicity:
1. tinnitus & metallic taste  in mouth
2. CNS toxicity (seizures)
3. cardiovascular (EKG changes, asystole)
